intro: Duvaliella problematica, commonly known as the problematic duvaliella, is a species of flowering plant native to certain regions of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and showy, five-petaled flowers that typically bloom in shades of pink or purple. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in shaded forest understories. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
